habitat_description:
The Lousiana pinesnake, as it name states, was historically found in west-central Louisiana and extreme east-central Texas (Conant and Collins 1991; Dundee and Rossman 1989; Jennings and Fritts 1983; Werler and Dixon 2000). In recent times, populations of this species are restricted to areas with abundant herbaceous ground cover, usually maintained by fires (Reichling 1990; Rudolph et al. 2006; Rudolph and Burgdorf 1997). Rudolph et al. (2006) concluded that extant populations occupy only a fraction of the historical range, west of the Mississippi River.

In general, the habitat consists of savanna, conifer woodland, and mixed woodland habitats. The preferred habitat is longleaf pine savannah that is characterized by well-drained, sandy soils (Reichling 1990; Rudolph and Burgdorf 1997). The authors reported burrowing in or using soil, but also decaying logs and leaf litter. The habitat is mainly characterized by pocket gopher burrows (Rudolph and Conner 1996).

In Texas, moist bottomlands are populated by this species in areas of long-leaf pine/oak sandhills, short-leaf pine/post oak forest, and blackjack oak woodlands. Habitats of preference include fields, farmland, sections of second-growth timber, and other openly wooded areas (Werler and Dixon 2000). In Louisiana, this species is only found in areas characterized by longleaf forests and second growth longleaf pine/blackjack oak (Fugler 1955; Walker 1965). 

SE	-Associations include short-leaf and long-leaf pine/oak forest and blackjack oak. Preferably found in openly wooded areas, and fields.
